title: The year's best poems: Forty Names by Parwana Fayyaz
text:
Names have power. WH Auden had a question he liked to use to test literary critics: “Do you like, and by like I mean really like, not approve of on principle, long lists of proper names such as the Old Testament genealogies or the Catalogue of the ships in The Iliad?” Auden would certainly have liked Parwana Fayyaz's Forty Names.

Ahead of this year’s Forward Prizes for Poetry, The Telegraph is publishing the five nominees for the Best Single Poem award. Fayyaz's shortlisted poem retells "a story told by my father or mother when I was a child," she says, "a story about forty women jumping off a cliff to preserve their honour.

"It is about a mountain called kohichehal dokhtaran, the forty girls’...
